#summary Your first specification starts here (adapted for the next version *1.2.7*)!
#labels Featured
(for more information, take a look at the [UserGuide User Guide])

  # declare a Specification object
{{{
import org.specs._

object helloWorld extends Specification {

}
}}}
  # a Specification is just a list of examples:
{{{
import org.specs._

object helloWorld extends Specification {
  "'hello world' has 11 characters" in {}
  "'hello world' matches 'h.* w.*'" in {}
}
}}}
  # back-up your examples with assertions:
{{{
import org.specs._

object helloWorld extends Specification {
  "'hello world' has 11 characters" in {
     "hello world".size mustBe 11
  }
  "'hello world' matches 'h.* w.*'" in {
     "hello world" must beMatching("h.* w.*")
  }
}
}}}

  # compile and run the class named *helloWorld*: `scala -cp bin helloWorld`
{{{
Specification "helloWorld"
  specifies 
  + 'hello world' has 11 characters
  + 'hello world' matches 'h.* w.*'

Total for specification "helloWorld":
Finished in 0 second, 63 ms
2 examples, 2 assertions, 0 failure, 0 error
}}}

  # now, you can more structure to your specification, by grouping your examples:
{{{
import org.specs._

object helloWorld extends Specification {
  "hello world" should {
    "have 11 characters" in {
      "hello world".size mustBe 11
    }
    "match 'h.* w.*'" in {
      "hello world" must beMatching("h.* w.*")
    }
  }
  "Good bye cruel world" should {...}
}
}}}

  # You can also use a JUnit runner to run your specification inside [http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1098/1433239972_5f3a83e40c.jpg?v=0  Eclipse] for example (using the JUnit4 library). Add: 
{{{
import org.specs.runner._
class helloWorldTest extends JUnit4(helloWorld)
}}}

*Note*: `helloWorldTest` is declared as a class and not an object to be instantiated properly by JUnit runners.
